White (University of Virginia School of Medicine, Charlottesville, VA). Hybridoma cells producing AC1-M11 mouse monoclonal antibodies specific for the α-chains of AP-2 (33Robinson M.S. J. Cell Biol. 1987; 104: 887-895Crossref PubMed Scopus (153) Google Scholar) were donated by Dr. Margaret S. Robinson (University of Cambridge, Cambridge, United Kingdom). AP.6 mouse monoclonal antibodies against the AP-2 α-chains (34Chin D.J. Straubinger R.M. Acton S. Nathke I. Brodsky F.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 9289-9293Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar) were collected from the media of AP.6 hybridoma cells (CRL-2227, American Type Culture Collection, Manassas, VA). Several cytoplasmic domain mutants with either strong or weak YXXZinternalization signals were prepared from the cDNA encoding A/Japan/305/57 HA and introduced into the SV40-based vector pkSVE (35Roth M.G. Doyle C. Sambrook J. Gething M.-J. J. Cell Biol. 1986; 102: 1271-1283Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). The mutants and their designations are depicted in Table I. Their derivation was described earlier (25Lazarovits J. Roth M.G. Cell. 1988; 53: 743-752Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar, 27Zwart D.E. Brewer C.B. Lazarovits J. Henis Y.I. Roth M.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 907-917Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar, 28Naim H.Y. Roth M.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3928-3933Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). For all these Japan HA mutants (including wt HA), we have also generated equivalent chimeric constructs with X:31 HA. In the X:31/Japan chimeras, the coding sequences for the external and transmembrane domains of X:31 HA were joined in-frame to the coding sequence of the short cytoplasmic domain of the various Japan HA mutants by “megaprimer” PCR mutagenesis (36Sarkar G. Sommer S.S. BioTechniques. 1990; 8: 404-407PubMed Google Scholar) in two rounds. First, pkSVE plasmids containing the various Japan HA mutant cDNAs were linearized and used as templates for PCR with a 5′-oligonucleotide encoding 18 bases of the X:31 HA region immediately preceding the transmembrane/cytoplasmic junction and 18 bases of the Japan HA sequence from the start of the region encoding the cytoplasmic domain. The 3′-oligonucleotide was 28 bases long, complementary to SV40 sequences 190 bases downstream from the first oligonucleotide, and encoded a SalI restriction site at the end. PCR produced a 190-base pair fragment that was isolated and used in a second round of PCR. The template for this round was pkSVEX31, containing X:31 HA cDNA in place of Japan HA; the sequence of X:31 HA cDNA is given in Ref. 37Gething M.-J. Bye J. Skehel J. Waterfield M. Nature. 1980; 287: 301-306Crossref PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar. A 5′-oligonucleotide with the sequence of the coding strand upstream from the unique XhoI site in X:31 HA was added with the 190-base pair chimeric fragment, which served as the 3′-primer. PCR generated a 530-base pair double-stranded DNA fragment, which was isolated, digested with XhoI andSalI, and used to replace the 530-base pair wild-typeXhoI-SalI fragment in pkSVEX31. The identity of the chimeric HAs was confirmed by sequencing. An additional mutant with a dileucine internalization signal was prepared from Japan HA by replacing the cytoplasmic sequence with that of the LIMP II protein following a previously described protocol (36Sarkar G. Sommer S.S. BioTechniques. 1990; 8: 404-407PubMed Google Scholar, 38Thomas D.C. Roth M.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 15732-15739Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). LIMP II contains a degenerate dileucine internalization motif with the sequence Leu-Ile as the third and fourth amino acids from the carboxyl terminus (39Sandoval I.V. Arredondo J.J. Alcalde J. Gonzalez Noriega A. Vandekerckhove J. Jimenez M.A. Rico M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 6622-6631Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). To facilitate PCR mutagenesis, the codon specifying Ile in the internalization signal was changed to specify Leu, which has been shown to function equally well (39Sandoval I.V. Arredondo J.J. Alcalde J. Gonzalez Noriega A. Vandekerckhove J. Jimenez M.A. Rico M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 6622-6631Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The cDNA sequence was confirmed by sequencing and encoded RGQGSTDEGTADERAPLLRT as the cytoplasmic domain. An XbaI-BamHI fragment containing the 3′-sequences of the chimeric cDNA was used to replace the same fragment in the expression vector pkSVEHA (40Naim H.Y. Roth M.G. Methods Cell Biol. 1994; 43: 113-136Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar). Zwart D.E. Roth M.G. Henis Y.I. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 115: 1585-1594Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar), and recombinant SV40 virus stocks for the various HA mutants in pkSVE vectors were prepared as described previously (41Naim H.Y. Roth M.G. J. Virol. 1993; 67: 4831-4841Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Cells were infected in suspension with second or third passage recombinant virus stocks (for protocol, see Refs. 28Naim H.Y. Roth M.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3928-3933Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar and 41Naim H.Y. Roth M.G. J. Virol. 1993; 67: 4831-4841Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The infected cells were plated either on glass coverslips (for immunofluorescence) or in tissue culture dishes (for co-immunoprecipitation studies). Experiments were preformed 36–38 h post-infection (for wt HA, HA+4, and HA-Y543) or after 44–46 h (for HA+8, HA-Y543,F546, and HA-Y543,L546) (for mutant nomenclature, see Table I). The longer infection time for the latter mutants, whose surface expression is low due to their fast internalization, was selected so that their surface density will be close to that of the other mutants (see Table I) (27Zwart D.E. Brewer C.B. Lazarovits J. Henis Y.I. Roth M.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 907-917Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar, 28Naim H.Y. Roth M.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 3928-3933Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Treatment with hypertonic medium to disperse the clathrin lattices underlying coated pits (42Heuser J.E. Anderson R.G.W. J. Cell Biol. 1989; 108: 389-400Crossref PubMed Scopus (767) Google Scholar, 43Hansen S.H. Sandvig K. van Deurs B. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 121: 61-72Crossref PubMed Scopus (295) Google Scholar) was performed by a 15-min incubation at 37 °C in Hanks' balanced salt solution containing 20 mm HEPES (pH 7.2) and 1% bovine serum albumin supplemented with 0.45 m sucrose (hypertonic buffer) (26Fire E. Gutman O. Roth M.G. Henis Y.I. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 21075-21081Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 29Fire E. Zwart D.E. Roth M.G. Henis Y.I. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 115: 1585-1594Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). In some experiments, the cationic amphiphilic drug chlorpromazine, which causes a redistribution of AP-2 from the plasma membrane to endosomes (44Subtil A. Hemar A. Dautry Varsat A. J. Cell Sci. 1994; 107: 3461-3468Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 45Wang L.H. Rothberg K.G. Anderson R.G. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 123: 1107-1117Crossref PubMed Scopus (923) Google Scholar), was added to cells at 100 µm in hypertonic buffer for 30 min at 37 °C. To measure the clustering of HA trimers directly at the surface of live cells, we employed immunofluorescence microscopy to detect antibody-mediated co-patching of antigenically distinct HA mutants as described (46Henis Y.I. Moustakas A. Lin H.Y. Lodish H.F. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 126: 139-154Crossref PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar, 47Gilboa L. Wells R.G. Lodish H.F. Henis Y.I. J. Cell Biol. 1998; 140: 767-777Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar, 48Gilboa L. Nohe A. Geissendorfer T. Sebald W. Henis Y.I. Knaus P. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2000; 11: 1023-1035Crossref PubMed Scopus (244) Google Scholar). Briefly, CV-1 cells co-infected with pairs of recombinant SV40 virus vectors expressing X:31/Japan or Japan HA mutants with identical cytoplasmic tails were plated on glass coverslips and incubated for the periods described above. Following hypertonic treatment (with or without chlorpromazine), the cells were processed with untreated controls for the co-patching experiments. All ensuing incubations were in the same buffer used for the treatment (Hanks' balanced salt solution containing 20 mm HEPES (pH 7.2) and 1% bovine serum albumin with or without sucrose and chlorpromazine) and were conducted at 4 °C to enable exclusive cell-surface labeling and to eliminate internalization. Under our experimental conditions, which combine low temperature (preventing the pinching off of vesicles from the membrane) and hypertonic treatment, there was no detectable internalization as validated both biochemically (by a Trypsin accessibility assay of IgG-labeled surface HA proteins) and by immunofluorescence (27Zwart D.E. Brewer C.B. Lazarovits J. Henis Y.I. Roth M.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 907-917Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar, 29Fire E. Zwart D.E. Roth M.G. Henis Y.I. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 115: 1585-1594Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). The cells were incubated successively with the following reagents: (i) HC3 mouse anti-X:31 IgG (50 µg/ml), rabbit anti-Japan IgG (50 µg/ml), and normal goat IgG (200 µg/ml, added for blocking) for 1 h; (ii) FITC-coupled goat anti-rabbit IgG (20 µg/ml) and biotinylated goat anti-mouse IgG (5 µg/ml) for 1 h; and (iii) Cy3-streptavidin (0.5 µg/ml) for 30 min. This protocol enhances the originally lower patching by monoclonal anti-X:31 IgG to a level similar to that of the rabbit anti-Japan IgG. After washing, the cells were fixed in methanol for 5 min at −20 °C and with acetone for 2 min at −20 °C and mounted with Mowiol containing 29 mm n-propyl gallate. Fluorescent digital images were acquired using a CCD camera as described (48Gilboa L. Nohe A. Geissendorfer T. Sebald W. Henis Y.I. Knaus P. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2000; 11: 1023-1035Crossref PubMed Scopus (244) Google Scholar). The FITC and Cy3 images were exported to Photoshop (Adobe, Mountain View, CA) and superimposed. The numbers of red, green, and yellow (superimposed red and green) patches were counted on the computer screen on 20 × 20-µm2flat cell regions; in each case, at least 100 patches were counted per cell on 10–15 cells. Experiments on the co-patching of AP-2 along with HA mutants followed a similar protocol using cells expressing only the Japan HA mutant. After patching the HA mutant at the cell surface with anti-Japan IgG followed by FITC-coupled goat anti-rabbit IgG, the cells were fixed/permeabilized by methanol and acetone, followed by labeling α-adaptin with AP.6 IgG (20 µg/ml in the presence of 200 µg/ml normal goat IgG, 45 min, 22 °C) and Cy3-coupled goat anti-mouse IgG (5 µg/ml, 45 min, 22 °C). CCD imaging and the counting of co-localized patches were carried out as described above for HA co-patching. CV-1 cells were co-infected with pairs of X:31/Japan and Japan HA mutants as in the co-patching studies and plated on 60-mm dishes for 36–46 h. After hypertonic treatment, each culture was solubilized in 0.3 ml/dish cold n-octyl glucoside lysis buffer (1% (w/v) n-octyl glucoside, 50 mm HEPES (pH 7.5), 150 mm NaCl, 10% glycerol, 1.5 mmMgCl2, 1 mm EGTA, and 1:100 dilution of protease inhibitor mixture). After nuclei and cell debris were removed, the relative amount of the Japan HA mutant in 20 µl of each lysate was determined by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (7% acrylamide) followed by Western blotting as described earlier (31Fire E. Brown C.M. Roth M.G. Henis Y.I. Petersen N.O. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 29538-29545Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar) using anti-Japan IgG (10 µg/ml) and peroxidase-coupled goat anti-rabbit IgG (1:10,000) for visualization by ECL. Blots were quantified by densitometry (described below) so that lysate volumes containing comparable amounts of the Japan HA form of each mutant were taken for immunoprecipitation. The lysates were diluted to 0.33%n-octyl glucoside and cleared by preincubation with protein A-Sepharose (40 µg/ml, 1 h, 40 °C), and the Japan HA mutant was precipitated by anti-Japan IgG (20 µg/ml, 2 h, 4 °C) and protein A-Sepharose (80 µg/ml, 2 h, 4 °C). The pellets were washed with buffer containing 0.1% n-octyl glucoside, 20 mm HEPES (pH 7.5), 150 mm NaCl, and 10% glycerol; dissolved and boiled in Laemmli loading buffer; and subjected to SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. The coprecipitated X:31/Japan HA mutants were identified by Western blotting with rabbit anti-X:31 IgG (15 µg/ml) and peroxidase-coupled goat anti-rabbit IgG (1:10,000). After washing, the filters were reacted for 5 min with SuperSignal and exposed to auto
